title-group.article-title: Effect of vacuum annealing on the microstructure and tribological behavior of hydrogenated amorphous carbon films prepared by magnetron sputtering

abstract.p: Hydrogenated amorphous carbon films (a-C:H) were prepared on silicon and steel substrates by medium frequency unbalanced magnetron sputtering with argon (Ar) and methane (CH4) as the source gases. The effect of annealing temperature in vacuum on the microstructure as well as mechanical properties and tribological behavior of as-prepared a-C:H films were investigated. The friction and wear behaviors of the films in different environments (vacuum, N2, and air) were evaluated with a pin-on-disk tribometer; and their sliding lifetime in vacuum was discussed in relation to friction and wear mechanisms. Results show that annealing in vacuum at a low temperature of up to 200 ℃ causes little change in the microstructure and hardness of a-C:H films but reduces their internal stress and surface roughness to some extent. These annealed films exhibit excellent antiwear ability in all test environments and show promising potential as a kind of space lubricants. The film begins to release hydrogen and increases the content of graphite-like structure at about 300 ℃. As a result, a-C:H films annealed above 200 ℃ have increased surface roughness as well as reduced hardness, internal stress, and wear resistance in all test environments.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Solid coatings are widely used in space mechanisms, since they perform well in the absence of gravity and in the presence of ionizing radiation under ultra-high vacuum within a wide operating temperature range.1–3 Particularly, amorphous hydrogenated carbon (a-C:H) film, as a solid lubricant for space tribology, has outstanding tribological characteristics including high wear resistance and ultra-low friction coefficient (0.001–0.01 in vacuum), as well as chemical inertness, infrared transparency and high electrical resistivity.4–6 However, its antiwear life is very short,7–9 which is the deadly problem limiting the use of a-C:H film as a space lubricant. Besides the loss of hydrogen from the film,9–11 the high internal stress leading to peeling-off of the a-C:H film from the substrate may also account for the limited lifetime in vacuum.12,13

To overcome the abovementioned drawback of a-C:H films, some researchers have actively attempted to alleviate the high internal stress of a-C:H films.10,14 However, few formulations are capable of offering good tribological performance in various environments. For example, annealing at moderate temperature can reduce the internal stress of a-C:H films15 and improve their tribological properties in air and nitrogen atmospheres,16–18 but too high annealing temperature may cause the relaxation of hydrogen and the transformation in C–C bonding from sp3 to sp2 and eventually leads to failure of the films.16,17,19–21

Beating that perspective in mind and noticing that few reports are currently available about the effect of annealing treatment on the tribological properties of a-C:H film as a space lubricant in both vacuum and ambient environments, in the present research we prepare magnetron sputtered a-C:H films and investigate the evolution of their microstructure, surface morphology, and tribological properties with annealing temperature in vacuum. The friction and wear mechanisms of as-annealed a-C:H films in vacuum are also highlighted.

sec.title: Film deposition and annealing treatment
sec.p: Unbalanced magnetron sputtering technique was adopted to deposit a-C:H films with a thickness of 1.4 µm on mirror-polished stainless steel (1Cr18Mn8Ni5N) and silicon substrates. The a-C:H films deposited on the stainless steel were used for friction and wear tests, and those deposited on Si substrate were used for characterization. Details of the deposition system have been described elsewhere.19 Briefly, a base pressure of about 6.0 × 10−3 Pa was attained in the chamber with a turbomolecular pumping system. The substrates were cleaned ultrasonically in an acetone bath and dried in air, followed by plasma etching with Ar+ ions in a vacuum chamber to remove the native oxides on the surface. A silicon interlayer with a thickness of about 200 nm was deposited on substrates by magnetron sputtering to improve the adhesion of the coatings to the substrates. Then a-C:H films were deposited with the mixed gas of Ar/CH4 (65 sccm/45 sccm; pressure 0.5 Pa) as the source gas. Magnetron sputtering was conducted under a graphite target sputtering current of 14 A, a substrate pulse bias voltage of −200 V, and a duty cycle of 20%. Thermal annealing treatment was conducted at 100 ℃, 200 ℃, 300 ℃, 400 ℃, and 500 ℃ for 2 h in a carbon nanotubes vacuum sintering furnace (2 T-50-22) at a pressure of 5.0 × 10−3 Pa and a heating rate of 5 ℃/min.

sec.title: Microstructure characterization
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the a-C:H films were recorded with an FTS165 spectrometer to detect the change of the hydrogen content. A nanoscope IIIa multimode atomic force microscope (AFM) was performed in tapping mode to observe the surface morphology of the films. The average surface roughness of the films over an area of 1 × 1 µm2 was calculated using the software attached to the AFM. The thickness of the film was measured by A Micro XAM 3D non-contact surface proﬁlometer: the substrate was marked before deposition and then the marked site was wiped by the acetone cotton ball after film deposition and the film on the marked site was removed as a result of poor adhesion without damaging the substrate.

The hardness value of the films was determined with a NanoTest 600 nanomechanical system (Micro Materials Ltd, UK), where the maximum indentation depth was controlled by computer to be about 150 nm (less than 10% of film thickness) so as to minimize the effect of the substrate. The curvature radii of the a-C:H ﬁlms were measured using a MicroXAM surface mapping microscope (ADE shift, America), and the internal stress was calculated based on Stoney equation20 σ=Es6(1-νs)(ts2tf)(1R2-1R1) where σ is the internal stress; R1 and R2 the substrate curvature radii before and after ﬁlm deposition; νs and Es the Poission ratio and Young modulus of the substrate; and ts and tf the thickness of the substrate and film,21 respectively.

sec.title: Evaluation of tribological properties
sec.p: The tribological properties of as-prepared a-C:H films were evaluated with a ball-on-disk tribometer equipped with a vacuum chamber. The photograph and schematic diagrams of the apparatus have been described elsewhere.22 Briefly, sliding tests of the films against steel ball counterpart (GCr15, Φ 6 mm) were run at a normal load of 5 N, a sliding speed of 300 r/min, a room temperature of about 20 ℃ and a maximum sliding duration of 3600 s while the wear track radius was fixed at 6 mm. As to the friction and wear tests in vacuum environment, a pressure of about 5.0 × 10−3 Pa was attained in the chamber with a turbomolecular pumping system. As to the friction and wear tests in N2 environment, the chamber was pumped to 1.7 × 10−4 Pa and then charged with dry pure N2 to maintain a pressure of 1.0 × 105 Pa. Before the friction and wear tests, the frictional pair was ultrasonically cleaned with acetone. Then the worn surfaces of the a-C:H films were observed with a JSM-5600LV scanning electron microscope (SEM); and their bonding and structure information before and after friction and wear tests in vacuum were obtained with a Jobin-Yvon HR-800 Raman spectrometer (excitation wavelength: 532 nm; the power density on samples was carefully controlled at 0.3 mW/m2 in order to minimize possible beam-heating effects).

sec.title: Bonding structure of a-C:H films
sec.p:
FT-IR spectrometry is widely used to characterize C–H bonding of a-C:H film, with which the intensity of C–H absorption peak is an indication of the content of bonded hydrogen.23 The FT-IR spectra of as-deposited a-C:H films and those annealed at different temperatures in vacuum are shown in Figure 1. The spectrum of the original film includes a main peak at 2920 cm−1 belonging to sp3 CH and sp3 CH2 asymmetric stretching mode, and two smaller shoulder peaks at 2950 and 2870 cm−1 corresponding to sp3 CH3 asymmetric and symmetric stretching mode, respectively.24,25 Besides, annealing in vacuum leads to decrease of bonded hydrogen content in as-annealed a-C:H films. When the annealing temperature is up to 300 ℃, there is only a slight reduction in the content of hydrogen and of C–H sp3 carbon. However, when the annealing temperature exceeds 300 ℃, the content of hydrogen and C–H sp3 carbon decreases drastically; and the peak intensity around 3050 cm−1 increases obviously, which suggests an increase of the content of C–H sp2 carbon.23,25 Figure 1.
IR spectra of as-deposited a-C:H film and a-C:H films annealed at different temperatures.

sec.title: Surface morphology of a-C:H films
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the three-dimensional AFM images of as-deposited and annealed a-C:H films. It can be seen that many islands with different sizes are randomly distributed on the films’ surface. The films annealed up to 200 ℃ have compact and atomically smooth surfaces, and their root mean square (RMS) roughness is below 1 nm. Once the annealing temperature exceeds 200 ℃, the isolated carbon islands undergo essential change in feature height, and the RMS roughness of the annealed films is relatively large (RMS >1 nm). We suppose that the defects and inter-atomic bonds in as-deposited a-C:H films are repaired during annealing in mild temperature region; and the dissociation of H2 molecules is retarded, both give rise to compact and smooth a-C:H films. Whereas, when as-deposited a-C:H films are annealed in high temperature region, hydrogen is released to form holes; and sp3 to sp2 transformation is accelerated to generate more graphite-like structure while surface diffusion generates sp2 rich cluster. As a result, a-C:H films annealed above 200 ℃ have a large surface roughness.26,27 Figure 2.
AFM images of as-deposited a-C:H film and a-C:H films annealed at different temperatures.

sec.title: Mechanical properties of a-C:H films
sec.p:
Figure 3 displays the hardness and internal stress of as-deposited a-C:H films and those annealed at different temperatures. It can be seen that annealing up to 200 ℃ leads to only a slight decrease in the hardness of a-C:H films, but annealing above 200 ℃ causes abrupt decrease in the hardness of the films (Figure 3(a)). It can be supposed that high hardness corresponds to a high fraction of sp3 bonds in a-C:H films, and low hardness implies a high percentage of sp2 bonds in relatively soft a-C:H films. In the meantime, all the a-C:H films exhibit compressive stress, and both the internal stress and hardness of a-C:H films decrease dramatically when annealing temperature up to 200 ℃ (Figure 3(b)). In combination with relevant analytical results of film structure, we can conclude that a-C:H films can release internal stress without significant changes in structure and hardness when they are annealed up to 200 ℃. Figure 3.
Hardness and internal stress of as-deposited a-C:H film and a-C:H films annealed at different temperatures.

The adhesion between the film and the substrate has significant influence on the wear life and bearing capacity of the a-C:H film.28 The critical load is usually used to evaluate the adhesion strength between the film and the substrate. Figure 4 shows the critical load of the film as-deposited and annealed at different temperatures. It can be seen that the critical load first increased then decreased with the increasing annealing temperature, and the film deposited at 200 ℃ has the maximum critical load, well corresponding to lowest internal stress. It is regarded that the internal stress can influence the adhesion of the film to the substrate.29 When the annealing temperature up to 200 ℃, the film begins to lose hydrogen and the structure of the film changes, as shown in Figure 1, as well as the film has a large surface roughness accompanied with hole appears on the surface and consequently the local interface stress will be affected,29 and thus the film has small critical load. Figure 4.
Critical load of as-deposited a-C:H film and a-C:H films annealed at different temperatures.

sec.title: Tribological behavior of a-C:H films
sec.p: Figure 5 shows the tribological behavior of as-deposited and annealed a-C:H films in different test environments (air, dry N2, and vacuum). It is seen that both the test environment and annealing temperature have significant effects on the tribological behavior of a-C:H films. When the films are tested in air, they show relatively high friction coefficients ranging from 0.05 to 0.1, and no obvious differences in friction coefficients are observed among as-deposited films and those annealed up to 200 ℃. However, when the annealing temperature rises to 400 ℃ or above, corresponding annealed a-C:H films show the highest friction coefficient of above 0.1 and are worn out quickly. In dry N2 environment, all the films maintain low friction coefficients (0.020–0.025) and long sliding lifetimes, except that the one annealed at 500 ℃ provides a highest friction coefficient of 0.09 and a shortest sliding lifetime of 1700 s. It seems that annealing below 500 ℃ has no obvious influence on the friction coefficient of the films in N2 environment. In vacuum environment, a-C:H films annealed at 100 ℃ and 200 ℃ have friction coefficients of about 0.005 after running-in stage; but as-deposited film and the one annealed at 300 ℃ are worn out after sliding for about 300 s, and the films annealed above 300 ℃ are worn out quickly.

In order to gain more insights into the friction and wear mechanisms of a-C:H films in vacuum, we have conducted SEM analysis of the wear tracks and Raman analysis of wear scars. Figure 6 shows the SEM pictures of the counterpart balls and the wear tracks of as-deposited a-C:H film and those annealed at 200 ℃ and 500 ℃, respectively. It can be clearly seen that the worn surface of the matched ball that slides against the as-deposited film is nearly no transfer film formed with small quantity of wear debris scattered around the wear scar. The matched ball that slides against the film annealed at 200 ℃ is covered by a thick and compact transfer film. The matched ball that slides against the film annealed at 500 ℃ is covered by loose and thick transfer film, and large debris accumulated around the wear scar. As shown in the wear track of the film, there is a large amount of bulge and breakages as well as some severe delamination in the wear tracks of as-deposited a-C:H film. The worn surface of the a-C:H film annealed at 200 ℃ is featured by mild wear and shows only a few wear debris; and the a-C:H film annealed at 500 ℃ is severely worn out to completely expose the stainless substrate. Figure 5.
Tribological properties of as-deposited a-C:H film and a-C:H films annealed at different temperatures in different test environments: (a) air, (b) dry N2, and (c) vacuum.

Raman spectrometry is a popular nondestructive and powerful tool to characterize the microstructure of carbon-based films, due to its ability to distinguish between different bonding types and domain sizes. When excited by visible light, as-prepared a-C:H films show Raman spectra that can be fitted into two Gaussian peaks: the D peak around 1350 cm−1 region assigned to the disordering of ordered graphite structure and the G peak around 1580 cm−1 assigned to graphite.30–32 Generally speaking, the G and D peaks of a conventional a-C:H film tend to shift toward a higher wavenumber and the D peak intensity (the area of the peak) tends to increase with decreasing sp3 bonding in the films, which corresponds to the decreased diamond-like characteristics of the films. We have investigated the Raman spectra of the as-deposited a-C:H film and the one annealed at 200 ℃ before and after friction and wear tests in vacuum. As shown in Figure 7, after friction and wear tests, as-deposited a-C:H film with the ratio of sp3/sp2 = 0.66 calculated by XPS spectra shows little change in the position of D and G peaks as well as in the peak intensity ratio (ID/IG, from 4.58 before friction and wear tests to 4.59 after friction and wear tests), which indicates that the failure of the as-deposited a-C:H film has no relation with its structure change. Similarly, the a-C:H film annealed at 200 ℃ also shows little change in the position of the G and D peaks; however, its ID/IG is reduced to some extent after the friction and wear tests (from 4.32 before friction and wear tests to 3.29 after friction and wear tests), which implies that sliding of the annealed a-C:H film against steel counterpart in vacuum leads to increase of the content of sp3 carbon in the contact region. This may be because hydrogen in the bulk film is able to replenish released hydrogen in the contact surfaces thereby saturating the dangling bonds during friction process. Figure 6.
SEM images of the worn surface on the counterpart balls slide against different films and corresponding films: (a) to (c) and (d) to (f) correspond to the worn surface for balls and a-C:H film as-deposited, annealed at 200 ℃ and annealed at 500 ℃.
Figure 7.
Raman spectra of the wear scars of: (a) as-deposited a-C:H film and (b) a-C:H film annealed at 200 ℃.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Under the selected conditions for magnetron sputtering deposition, as-deposited a-C:H films are highly hydrogenated and consist of a cross-linked amorphous network of carbon with all possible C hybridizations (sp1, sp2, and sp3). Moreover, the hydrogen incorporation during the deposition causes a high compressive stress and generates non-equilibrium a-C:H film. When a-C:H film is annealed in vacuum, its structure will be reorganized to become more stable, which is related with two relaxation mechanisms: (a) instantaneous local relaxation initiated by the access energy dissipated in the thermalization stage and (b) long-term (thermally assisted) relaxation via different or local rearrangement.33 The relaxation ways include the sp3 to sp2 transformation, sp2 clustering and the effusion of hydrogen. The threshold temperature for hydrogen effusion varies obviously depending on different manufacturing methods, deposition parameters, and ambient atmospheres.34 In this research, although the a-C:H film annealed at 300 ℃ has a slightly reduced content of bounded hydrogen, its total hydrogen content rapidly drops.35 The effect of the annealing on the structure and composition of a-C:H films can be divided into two stages. When a-C:H films are annealed up to 200 ℃, the defects and inter-atomic bonds in the films are repaired during annealing. As a result, the surface roughness of the film is reduced, and its content of bonded hydrogen as well as hardness is slightly reduced (Figures 1 to 3). Whereas, at high annealing temperature of above 200 ℃, a large number of hydrogen in the film is released and the sp3 to sp2 transformation is enhanced to generate more graphite-like structure. As a result, the sp3-CH stretching mode almost vanishes and the sp2-CH stretching mode gains (Figure 1). The formation of a large number of sp2 cluster in a-C:H films is always associated with diffusion to form different sizes islands that are randomly distributed in the carbon films, thereby preferentially leading to substantial roughening of the film surface (Figure 2).36 Besides, the high percentage of sp2 bonds favors to decrease the distortion of bond length and angle in sixfold carbon rings thereby decreasing the carbon network rigidity and film hardness (Figure 3).36

The internal stress of a-C:H films continuously decreases with the increase of annealing temperature (Figure 3), which is quite different from the variation of hardness therewith and indicates a different stress release mechanism. Usually, increasing annealing temperature leads to structural relaxation associated with ordering of sp2 cluster and decrease of defect density, thereby reducing the internal stress.37 In the meantime, fine nanocrystalline graphite in amorphous carbon network can efficiently reduce the internal stress through grain boundary sliding and grain boundary diffusion during high temperature annealing.28 Moreover, the release of the internal stress of a-C:H films associated with annealing can be divided into two stages. The first stage covers the release of stress induced by ion bombardment at an annealing temperature of up to 200 ℃, and the second stage covers the stress release owing to the effusion of hydrogen from a-C:H films at an annealing temperature above 200 ℃.16

The tribological properties of a-C:H films are highly dependent on the test environments and annealing temperatures (Figure 4). On one hand, the effect of annealing on the tribological properties of a-C:H films is associated with the change in their structure and mechanical properties. On the other hand, the effusion of hydrogen and the sp3 to sp2 transformation caused by annealing lead to increase of the content of graphite-like structure with poor mechanical properties thereby worsening wear resistance.16 Upon the hydrogenation of carbon atom on the sliding surface of a-C:H films, the adhesion interactions between the sliding surfaces of the films and steel counterpart are reduced, thereby lowering and stabilizing friction coefficient. In air environment, water and oxygen can interact physically and chemically with surface carbon atoms to form a layer of physico-chemisorbed species that can be replenished quickly.38,39 Such a layer of physico-chemisorbed species can induce the oxidation of a-C:H films and cause strong adhesion between the sliding surfaces of the films and steel counterpart under friction-induced heat, thereby leading to high friction coefficients with steep fluctuations. In dry N2 environment, no tribochemical reactions are involved, but a-C:H films are able to form transfer films on the sliding surface of counterpart steel ball, thereby preventing the direct contact between the a-C:H films and the steel ball thus maintaining low friction coefficients.4 However, a-C:H film annealed at 500 ℃ shows the highest friction coefficient and poor wear resistance, possibly because it is severely graphitized so that it resembles a-C film, also its rougher surface causes high level of mechanical interlocking between surface asperities thereby leads to high frictional forces (especially during the running-in or initial stages of sliding tests).40

Moreover, the vacuum tribological properties of a-C:H films are quite different from those in air and dry N2 environments, which implies that they may undergo different friction and wear mechanisms in different test environments. Generally speaking, internal stress, hydrogen, and surface roughness all have significant effects on the sliding lifetime of a-C:H films. The action mechanism of the internal stress can be illustrated, as shown in Figure 8: intrinsic internal stress is generated in a-C:H films during their growing process. When extrinsic load or contact stress exceeds a critical value, the internal stress can be relaxed, and microcrack can occur in a-C:H films.41–43 In terms of the action mechanism of hydrogen in vacuum, free hydrogen will quickly overflow along the microcrack under the action of negative pressure, and the hydrogen released from the film surface under friction-induced heat and mechanical action cannot be well replenished; as a result, the state of ultra-low friction and wear can remain only in a very short duration. As to the action mechanism of surface roughness, the a-C:H films annealed up to 200 ℃ have decreased internal stress and surface roughness as well, but their content of total hydrogen remains almost unchanged after annealing.35 As a result, the hydrogen bounded with the carbon atoms on the sliding surface of the film leads to low friction coefficients in vacuum. The long sliding lifetime of a-C:H films may be related to several factors. First, the intrinsic internal stress of a-C:H films, attributed to the accumulative effect of flaws that are built into the films during the deposition process, can be released during sliding, and thus avoiding the peeling-off of the films from the substrate.44 Second, physical and mechanical interactions play an important role in friction losses;45 moreover, annealing at proper temperatures favors to lower the surface roughness of a-C:H films and their adhesion interactions with counterpart steel. Third, the stable and uniform transfer film of a-C:H films has weak chemical or physical interaction with sliding counterpart, which can avoid the direct contact between the film and counterpart.46 The a-C:H films annealed above 200 ℃ undergo dramatic hydrogen overflow; and the rapid drop in hydrogen content causes the collapse of the films and transformation from sp3 to sp2 structure, thus providing a highly graphitized layer at sliding interface.35 Meanwhile, a-C:H films annealed above 200 ℃ have larger surface roughness, which may facilitate severe adhesion interactions between the sliding surfaces of the films and steel counterpart; also, the hydrogen released into the contact zone of the frictional pair cannot be well replenished. As a result, high friction coefficient and large wear mass loss are observed for the a-C:H film annealed above 200 ℃. Figure 8.
The mechanisms of internal stress release in a-C:H films.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The effect of annealing temperature in vacuum on the microstructure as well as mechanical and tribological properties of a-C:H films has been investigated. It has been found that increasing annealing temperature causes decrease in the content of bonded hydrogen and increase in the content of ordered sp2 cluster. Both the hardness and internal stress of a-C:H films tend to decrease with rising annealing temperature. The structure and hardness of a-C:H films remain almost unchanged after annealing up to 200 ℃, but their internal stress and surface roughness are obviously decreased favoring to good tribological properties of the films in various test environments. Annealing a-C:H films above 200 ℃ causes the effusion of hydrogen, transformation from sp3 to sp2 structure, and increase of surface roughness, which leads to decreased hardness and internal stress as well as poor tribological properties of a-C:H films in all test environments.
